conversation.content: [惊吓地] Marcus？是你——
哦天哪，Jamie！这也太巧了吧，我昨天Boxify那个项目黄了的时候还正好想起你呢。
[紧张] 哦对，Boxify的项目。所以你已经知道了，那咱俩在机场偶遇这事儿就更尴尬了。
等等，你说我知道是什么意——哦。哦不是吧。别告诉我你们就是跟我们抢那个合同的创业公司。
抢这个词用得太客气了。你们公司那个环保方案直接把我们碾压了，不过现在说这些也没意义了，反正我们下个月就要关门了。
Jamie，我真不知道那是你的公司。标书上就写着"NovaPack Solutions"，我根本没往那方面想。[呼气] 天哪，要是我知道的话...
知道了又怎样？故意输掉？拜托，Marcus，咱们都清楚现在商场是什么样。这又不是大二那会儿，一起吃泡面一起熬夜的时候了。
[防备地] 这不公平吧。我至少会联系你的，说不定咱们能合作或者找个双赢的办法，而不是这样互相竞标。
合作。是啊。你们公司4000万的融资，想跟我这个连工资都快发不出来的车库小作坊合作。[苦笑]
[轻声地] 也不是一开始就有4000万的。我也是从车库起步的，你还记得吗？毕业那年夏天，你去读研，我靠信用卡度日的时候？
[更轻柔] 嗯，记得。你还给我发过第一个原型机的照片，用麦片盒和胶带做的。其实我一直留着呢。
你还留着？[惊讶地笑] 这个...我以为Sarah和租房那些破事儿之后，你早就把所有东西都删了。
[怅然地] 没有，好的东西我都留着。那是在一切变复杂、咱们断联之前的事。15年了，还为大学那点破事儿较劲，是不是太久了？
确实太久了。听着，我知道现在说这个时机特别不好，你公司的事儿...但要是落地后能一起喝个咖啡？如果你不是要转机的话。
[犹豫地] 我不知道这样是不是...算了，你知道吗？行吧。反正我也没有公司要赶回去了。[苦笑]
[小心地] Jamie，如果——先听我说完——如果NovaPack还能挽救点什么呢？我们正好在找人负责一个新部门。
求你别给我安排什么同情工作，Marcus。那比输掉合同还让人难受。我还有点自尊的。
[诚恳地] 不是同情。
不是？那是什么？在我看来，就是我那个成功的前室友因为不小心搞垮了我的公司而内疚呗。
[坚定地] 是我看到人才就想要。你的方案很精彩，Jamie，创新程度我们根本比不上。我们赢在基础设施，不是创意。我需要思维不一样的人，而你一直都是这样的人。

original_conversation.content: [startled] Marcus? Is that—
Oh my god, Jamie! This is completely surreal, I was literally just thinking about you yesterday when the Boxify deal fell through.
[tense] Right, the Boxify deal. So you know about that already, which makes this whole accidental airport run-in thing even more awkward than it needs to be.
Wait, what do you mean I know about—oh. Oh no. Don't tell me you're the startup we were competing against for that contract.
Competing is a generous word for what happened. Your company basically crushed us with that sustainability pitch, not that it matters now since we're shutting down operations next month anyway.
Jamie, I had no idea it was your company. The proposal just came through as 'NovaPack Solutions' and I never made the connection. [exhales] God, if I'd known...
You'd what? Have thrown the pitch? Come on, Marcus, we both know how the business world works now. It's not like sophomore year when we'd share ramen and pull all-nighters together.
[defensive] That's not fair. I would have at least reached out, maybe we could have collaborated or found some way to work together instead of bidding against each other.
Collaborated. Right. Your company with its forty million in funding wants to collaborate with my garage startup that can barely make payroll. [bitter laugh]
[quietly] It wasn't always forty million. I started in a garage too, remember? That summer after graduation when you went to grad school and I was living off credit cards?
[softer] Yeah, I remember. You sent me that photo of your first prototype made from cereal boxes and duct tape. I still have it somewhere, actually.
You kept that? [surprised laugh] That's... I mean, I figured you'd deleted everything after that whole mess with Sarah and the lease situation.
[wistful] No, I kept the good stuff. Before everything got complicated and we stopped talking. Fifteen years is a long time to hold onto old college drama, isn't it?
Way too long. Look, I know this is terrible timing with your company and everything, but maybe we could grab coffee when we land? If you're not connecting somewhere else, I mean.
[hesitant] I don't know if that's... actually, you know what? Sure. It's not like I have a company to rush back to anymore anyway. [rueful laugh]
[carefully] Jamie, what if—and just hear me out—what if there was a way to salvage something from NovaPack? We're actually looking for someone to head up a new division.
Please don't offer me a pity job, Marcus. That's somehow worse than losing the contract in the first place. I've got some dignity left.
[earnest] It's not pity.
No? Then what is it? Because from where I'm sitting, it looks like my successful former roommate feeling guilty about accidentally destroying my company.

[firmly] It's me recognizing talent when I see it. Your proposal was brilliant, Jamie, innovative in ways ours wasn't. We won on infrastructure, not ideas. I need someone who thinks differently, and that was always you.

scenario: Two college roommates reunite by chance at an airport gate after fifteen years, when one's packaging design company just lost the contract that would have saved the other's struggling startup.
